OMG they increased the prices 40-80% for most dishes. This is ridiculous. 16 dollars for bread??? Used to be $9. Kale and crab rangoon was $13 now $18. None of the plates 2 years ago even got close to hitting 30 dollars they were all 20-25. The spatzle dishes used to 15 now its 20. Carrot crepe was 13 now its 20. The frozen yogurt used to be 9 dollars now its 13. Covid inflation is real and very present in this restaurant because they choose to raise the prices to compensate but that's not great for the community. The community has been dedicated to going to to your restaurant and now you are robbing them. I'm glad I went here a lot when prices were reasonable. I won't be coming back ever until prices go back to what they were.
Incredible meal. The carrot crepe was a standout. The watermelon cocktail was also excellent. Pricey but worth it.
One of the most creative and delightful meals of all time! Great service and atmosphere, loved the garden space. Don't wait to get here!!
No comment

Had dinner here for the first time after hearing good things. The staff was courteous and knowledgeable and the service was seamless. The food was a delicious sensory experience. Come here with an open mind and enjoy the ride.

We had such an amazing time here. The outdoor dining in the garden is so romantic. Even in the pouring rain. We shared the summer salad, the steak skewers, the fried chicken. You can't go wrong with anything you order here and I look forward to coming back when they have their full menu. The wait staff is superb and gracious. The little store in front is adorable. Can't wait to come back. I can't thank you guys enough for the plastic bags to put over my white shoes in the torrential downpour! We had a blast xoxo!

Our first time here, and its our new favorite. Everything was wonderful. The food, and ambiance was all so comforting. The main room seemed a bit loud, so if you'd like a more intimate setting the garden is the way to go. We will be back to try all the new season menus.

Just so-so. We had the pre fixe with the wine pairing. The timing was all over the place, we were there for 2.5 hours. The wine would get poured for the next course and we'd wait another 20 min for the food that was supposed to go with it. Didn't have water on the table for half the meal. The food was good but it left us thinking "what can we have for a snack when we get home?"

Overall a really lovely meal and atmosphere. We loved the fried veggie and einkorn bread The duck pastrami was also really good, but I forgot to get a picture. The spatzle also good. The tomato schnitzel was okay, I wish it was crunchier but I think the wet tomato was working against the crunchy. Cocktails were also great. The fro-yo dessert is really original but it is A LOT of honey, you have to like honey.
No comment

Came for breakfast today. There was no wait however we were limited to the bar. Interior is beautiful and Trendy, beautiful garden in the back. Staff was pleasant and welcoming. We tried The matcha cocktail which was good but sweeter than expected. For entrees the burger was delicious juicy as it was half sausage and half beef patty topped with onions , cheese and This incredible sauce.  The eggs crab Benedict was okay , and interesting twist on traditional way as it's served.

I was really looking forward to my visit to Olmsted, but we were very disappointed. Ee were seated where the air conditioner was dripping next to me. I was unhappy with the Ramp cocktail. I am a big fan of Gin Gibsons, and this drink just had way too much vinegar. I could not drink it and sent it back. We thought that Watermelon Sushi was terrible, all you tasted was bonito flakes. It was a waste of good fish. We liked the carrot crepe. The crab rangoons were under seasoned, and it was just poor presentation that the dumplings did not fit in the bowl for the sauce. We got the smoked duck - which was way to smokey - the duck was tender, and that was good - but you tasted only smoke. It was a waste of a good piece of duck. The scallops were prepared well, BUT - that corn/blueberry sauce was not good. We also had to wait 20 minutes for the scallops. I think the server did not put the order in until we checked in with her. I appreciated not being charged for the Ramp cocktail. Overall it was a big disappointment! I would not recommend Olmsted and I doubt I will be interested in trying it out again.

Really really good food. They had a lot of squash on the menu the night we ate there:  battered delicata rings for an appetizer, the bread had squash in it, and there was a honeynut squash entree. Skipped the bread but the other two were excellent, as was the the duck liver mousse and the short ribs. Where they were less than perfect was service. We waited 3 minutes inside for someone to greet and seat us, with no acknowledgment from the bartender or any of the wait staff who saw us standing here, not even an eyebrow raise or nod or "we'll be with you shortly". Our server was very nice but extremely soft spoken (the restaurant is NOT QUIET) so we had to have her repeat things again and again. And the dietary restriction thing got a little...forced. Both of us have some - not allergies, more like strong preferences - and we told the server we could figure it out. She kept questioning us - are you vegetarian? Pescatarian? We said no, and no allergies so nothing for the kitchen to worry about, but we can work it out when we look at the menu. "But are you pescatarian?" Back off, we got it.

This place is extremely average for the price. I was with a group of 4 and the waitress actually recommended we order the entire menu because of the portions if we were hungry or 9 dishes if we weren't that hungry! Seriously!? We started off ordering cocktails and my mezcal cocktail was good, but nothing special. We first had the duck mousse that was actually pretty decent and the crudo was decent as well, but not memorable. The brussel sprouts were basically a bowl of burnt brussel sprouts leaves with truffle shavings on top, very boring. The roasted butternut squash was a joke for $30. This was probably the worst dish I have every ordered for over $30, EVER. I could honestly make a better butternut squash dish at home. The scallops were another joke. Two tiny scallops on sticks with some lettuce with for $34?! Everything is so outrageously overpriced it is comical how people would even come here when there are so many better options in the neighborhood for that type of money. Save your money and go somewhere better.

I was really looking forward to trying Olmsted for months but left feeling a little underwhelmed. The squash onion rings were great but I really wish there were more of them.. 4 small rings for $15 felt a bit ridiculous. The banana squash bread and the root vegetable som tum were blah. We also got the crab and kale rangoon, which kind of just tasted like spinach and artichoke dip.. no crab in them. The lobster spatzle and the roasted and confit duck were delicious and definitely the standouts. The arctic char was also pretty good. Overall, there were a couple good dishes but most of them fell flat.

I had been wanting to try Olmsted as this place has received a lot of positive press. My overall score is 3.5, but I rounded down to 3 stars due to the 10% Covid charge, charging $8 for bread when not telling us about the additional charge, and the small portion sizes. The squash rings, bacon & brussel sprout pierogies, bread & butter and the smoked duck breast were the highlights of the thanksgiving pre-fix. Our meal was very pricey for the small amount of food that we received (over $200 per person). I'm glad that I tried this place, but it's not worth the hype.

Totally overpriced. Service was good but food was just "meh". Wagyu hotdog? I don't understand the point of it. Tasted like a regular corn dog to me. All of the dishes we got were nothing special and seemed quite pricey for what they were.

We just had a beautiful, delicious and decadent birthday dinner at olmstead! The food was beautifully presented and each dish looked like a piece of art. The backyard was gorgeous with lush greens and twinkly lights. We ate the crab Rangoon, som tum salad, spaetzle and carrot and scallop crepe. The carrot crepe was especially memorable with a luscious and sweet sauce. For dessert, don't miss the lavender honey frozen yogurt!

Dinner at Olmstead was delicious, the flavors were fun and interesting, and the cocktail menu is well done. But the real highlight was our server, Emma, who made the night special with her great recommendations and cool ease. Not sure the food is worth all the hype of the place, but it was solid. Emma is definitely worth the hype. Thank you for a lovely dinner!

It's been 4 1/2 years since we came for dinner. This time we got to dine in the back garden (it's closed last time due to rain). The cocktails (lavender, rosemary and rhubarb) set us in the mood. Knowing that the portions tended to be small, we ordered all the snacks and plates (except the liver mousse eclairs) on the menu including double orders of corn bread and Crab Rangoon for six of us. The delicious corn bread with honey truffle butter was a crowd pleaser. The crab Rangoon served in a Chinese takeout container was tasty. We barely got a morsel of dainty carrot crepe and minuscule clams. Tiny samples of the other snacks/plates including yellow wax beans, spaetzle, squash som tum, and lobster crackers that came in quick succession, found nothing spectacular. Then there was a long interlude before the mains arrived  Of the entrees the roasted duck confit was superb: tender, juicy and flavorful. The scallops tasted very fresh. The tomato schnitzel would have been great if the crust/tomato could be crispier. The froyo dessert and shortcake were satisfactory. Our dinner spanned 2 1/2 hours. Good thing we came armed with bug repellent that made us impervious to becoming insect feast on this summer night. Pippa our server provided excellent service.

I was nervous to eat here since I am vegan, but was pleasantly surprised that they had many options they could make/modify for me. They even had veganise to accompany the build your own BLT dish. I highly recommend you check Olmsted out for some delicious food and great drinks!

Amazing dining! Acorn squash soup was excellent. Tempura broccoli rabe was good and crispy and perfectly fried. Tagliatelle was a fun surprise as we didn't realize it wasn't actual pasta but a root vegetable. I really enjoyed the sauce.  Scallops very good but sauce was a bit too spicy. Chocolate mousse was impressive. The Rosemary cocktail was great but the Rye bread was not for me but may be more enjoyable to whisky lovers. The outdoor backyard space was so quaint and comfortable to be in and the staff were incredibly helpful. A bit pricey but worth it!

Olmsted is one of my favorite restaurants in Brooklyn! I have been here for brunch and dinner. Both meals were fantastic. This time for brunch, my friend and I ordered the duck liver mousse, BEC egg rolls, duck duo, potato latke, and the donuts for dessert. We loved everything but would have gone without the egg rolls. Our server was extremely nice and took the egg rolls off of our check. We weren't expecting that when she asked what we thought of them. She suggested that we get them initially so I guess she felt bad that we didn't like it.

Perfect experience every time! Very creative, thoughtful, and delicious food. Welcoming and warm atmosphere. Attentive and friendly service. So yes if you are wondering - go for brunch! Go for dinner! They even have a magical garden in the back where you can admire all the botany and sparkly lights from any of the various cozy seating nooks and from where you can dine or just have drinks/dessert.

After the Covid lecture about how one must wear a mask except while eating, our party of 5 perused the menu. We had a couple of questions about some of the selections. The server told us that they usually recommend that with a party our size we order one of "everything" on the menu so each of us could get a couple of bites. While the lunch menu wasn't huge, that would cost approx. $250 not including drinks. We were told that each dish would be served as soon as it was prepared which would have been fine except for the very very long delay for 2 of the entrees. I'm not complaining about the food...it was memorable, creative, and delicious, but I felt the experience was a bit snooty and pretentious. Maybe a better place to take a date with whom you want to impress!

Don't get it. Whole experience was so random and hodgepodge. Thought it was Farm to table? It's more like seafood dragged through the garden, weird. Service was pretentious from the hostess to the server.  Doesn't deserve the hype. Thank goodness for the taco food truck parked curbside in front of the restaurant.
Worth the price! Yes, the reviews are true. DELIIIIIIICIOUS!! Staff is polite and efficient. Looking forward to going back here again!

I've been wanting to go here since they opened and after having my plans thwarted multiple times, we finally made it for brunch. If we lived nearby, we'd always be here. I wasn't a huge fan of the gravlax, but did love that they could do almost everything gluten free. The GF squash bread was amazing, especially with the butter and jam, served hot. My friends loved the donuts. The Vietnamese pizza was also a hit. The mushrooms were outstanding. The kathi roll was interesting, but we were stuffed by the time we got it. And I don't know that I'd order it again. I'll definitely be back to try dinner.

Really good. Although nothing I ate blew me away, so that's why it was 4 stars instead of 5. We enjoyed 4 dishes, kale crab ragoon, some lamb appetizer, and scallops and duck for dinner. Everything was very good, although the lamb appetizer was just ok. I also enjoyed a really good whiskey drink with black walnut, I think it may have been called the Lavender. The service was also fairly poor, which was weird because it seemed like a lot of staff around, but I ended up not trying a second drink because no one ever came by, which was odd. The lady pouring the wine in particular seemed to be joking around a lot, which seemed very unprofessional. Not sure why this place has a month long wait for reservations, it's good but not a month long wait good.
Beautiful place with garden, good food and friendly staff. Love to come back. Bloody Mary is legit and the brunch is definitely a good time to come.

Not entirely sure how I have friends who can get reservations here after all that hype from the media, which is really well deserved. I delayed writing this review but can still distinctly remember the taste of every dish we ordered. The best plates were easily the duck chakna and Dave's trout for me, but people were also loving the carrot crepe, uni pierogis and popcorn monkfish. The guinea hen was a slight disappointment given how salty it was, but the confit was still a win. Drinks have low ABV but are mostly enjoyable. Desserts seem rather unsophisticated and not my cup of tea. But overall the best meal I have had in 2017 so far.
I spent very good moments here.Very good cooking,very warm inside,very friendly staff.Everything is perfect.

Wow! I was not sure whether Olmstead would live up to the hype, but it sure did in my book. We went with friends visiting from PA and took the 5:30 reservation (it was that or 10:00). They have a lovely cocktail menu and managed to try 6 different drinks, all of which were quite good. The menu is broken up into starters, small plates, and slightly larger plates. Our server recommended 3 dishes per person and the whole menu was 14 dishes I think, so we agreed on 5 things we didn't want and ordered the rest of the menu and shared. We really liked everything although some dishes really stood out - the pork belly was so good we got seconds! For dessert, they usher you put to the garden to clear up table space; fortunately it was a nice evening. The chocolate mousse was to die for, the guys had the s'mores and enjoyed cooking marshmallows. I'll be back.

Great atmosphere, highly in tune waitstaff, and definitely bustling on a Saturday night. Quite a show from the bar, since you can see the entire kitchen adjacent to you. Reservations are a must, and take a number because there's a stand-by list also. We trusted recommendations from our bartender/waiter, and we were not disappointed. Their Duck Confit dish was one of the most outrageously delicious things I have ever had. Soft corn cake, slow cooked duck, and sliced breast on the side make for a ton of flavor. Watch out for that Dan Dan Spaetzle. There's a reason there are 3 red peppers next to it, so grab a beer while enjoying. Our party of two tried a little of everything, and had an undetermined amount of wine. It was under $250, and I considered it dinner and a show.

We had an incredible meal at Olmsted tonight with wonderful service. Emma guided us through the menu expertly for both drinks and food, and everything we got (almost everything on the menu) was inventive and delicious. The music is great and the atmosphere overall was awesome. The s'mores outside in the garden was the cherry on top of a lovely dining experience!

A beautiful space with great service. Brunch menu is ok. Nothing particularly captured us on the page, but we settled on the duck liver mousse (phenomenal), the potato latke (lackluster), and the burger (ok, too much sauce and didn't come out at the temperature we requested). We had the drip coffee (watered down and a bit sour), fresh squeezed OJ (yum yum), and the carrot OJ mimosa (ok). Overall, not what I expected considering how much I've heard about this place.

I came with my friend who just delivered her son 4 weeks ago (in a mask during a pandemic). I was coming from Manhattan with my husband and 9 month old son and had to drop them off so I could park the car. They wouldn't seat my friend despite them asking and explaining the situation multiple times (my friend physically was in pain and would have felt more comfortable seated). Honestly, I thought their behavior was absolutely disgusting.

Really good brunch spot.  I had high expectations and they were met. We started with drinks, I had a Virgin Mary and it was amazing.  We ordered the potatoe latke, butternut squash bread, duck duo, and spinach borek. Everything was delicious.  Service was attentive and water was constantly refilled. They are fairly small plates but we were stuffed with the amount we got. Can't wait to return to try other menu items.

DO NOT GO IF YOU ARE A VEGAN, VEGETARIAN OR PESCATARIAN. Literally one of the worst meals we have ever received. We paid for a multiple course dinner and the vegan and vegetarian had to sit most of the courses out. Of course, we were told before making our reservation the restaurant "absolutely could" accommodate a vegan and pescaratian. The vegan was literally served a slice of potato on a plate (that was it!) and for dessert a "fruit platter" which was a bowl of sliced apples and CANNED MANDARIN ORANGES. The pescatarian didn't fare much better- a tiny piece of bland fish with mushy broccoli on top- nothing else- no sides, nothing. It was very insulting for the price. Meanwhile, the meat-eaters in our party had multiple courses and sides with their meals. Again, if you are a vegan, vegetarian or pescatarian stay far away from this place. Very disappointing. We left feeling insulted.
Great food for brunch--shareable dishes and a cute garden put back where you can wait for your table. Loved the vibe and the breakfast burger is amazing!

Had their Thanksgiving prefix last night at the outdoor back area, decor was beautiful but even though it was relatively warm for the season we still found it chilly, the closed section of the back area does not have any heaters on it so dining here when it gets colder is definitely out of the question. Service was fine, food was generally good (but to be honest my favorite course was the bread and butter), wine pairings were underwhelming but cocktails were good for the price. Lavender yogurt dessert was exceptional. They lose one star for sneaking in a Covid fee that they didn't tell us about in advance even though they had plenty of opportunities to (multiple confirmation e-mails, etc). I'm all for contributing and encouraging restaurants to stay in business, but adding a 10% charge at the last minute felt very shady. The meal was expensive enough, if you want to raise prices just raise prices.

We can't wait to go back to Olmsted.

This place looks like your friendly little neighborhood spot, but it definitely lives up to its pedigree. The chawanmushi is a must try with it's perfect balance and umami. The carrot crepe little neck clams with sunflower was so good, we got two orders. The rutabaga tagliatelle had the perfect brown butter/butternut squash taste and the texture was "al dente with a crunch." A few things you can skip are: crawfish boil crackers, the lamb. If you're in Brooklyn, I think it's a must try.

The best farm-to-table dining experience in Brooklyn. Truly delicious, innovative dishes served in a comfortable, inviting dining room by warm, welcoming, knowledgeable and efficient staff. The standard of cooking is very high and very consistent. Great every time.

So I was going to wait to review this place until I actually ate dinner there, but the positive experience that I had here prompted me to share. I went there during early evening on Wednesday. I didn't have a reservation and was totally cool with the option of sitting in their lovely garden. We ordered some cocktails. We were a group of 4 and we each ordered a different one so I was able to taste each unique concoction! I loved their smoky Mezcal cocktail! Their garden featured all of their freshly grown herbs and veggies, all of which make an appearance in their farm to table dishes. They even had a little hen house. I was at ease and the world made sense again!

Very cute place and a lovely garden (which unfortunately  closed before we could get there to enjoy our dessert.)

Was so glad I could finally visit Olmstead for brunch when I had family in town. We visited on a Friday and it was so lovely. We had all of the Instagram favorites: the egg rolls, the potato pancake and the liver mousse. I can't remember what cocktails we got but they were delicious! The restaurant itself is so fun; you can visit their garden with live chickens in the back. As instagram-baity the egg rolls were, I still talk about them! They were so delicious; I immediately wanted more! Will be back, hopefully sooner than later.
Amazing service and food. Walked in and got a table. The backyard garden looked great. Definitely recommend checking it out.

This restaurant is my go-to for a special meal. I always have to ask (or secretively Google) what the items on the menu are, but I have yet to be disappointed with the flavors and presentation. I highly recommend.

OMG we had the most mediocre post-thanksgiving day brunch here. $75 for a pre-fixe family style menu. That's $150 for a 5-inch piece of cornbread (to share), a small radicchio salad (to share), 1 small cast iron pan with runny eggs and string beans, 2 fried egg rolls, and a large waffle for dessert that was probably the most filling item, except for $150 we did not expect to be left most filled by the waffle (we were still hungry at the end of the meal even after the waffle). The meal was edible but a complete rip off. I lost my taste for it shortly after I realized we were being ripped off just as the tiny egg rolls arrived. I wanted to try what they had to offer but felt forced to eat what it seemed they felt like making that morning. Seems like this place takes themselves way too seriously if they think what they served this past Friday was worthy of such a high tab!

Olmsted is one of my favorite restaurants in Brooklyn! The dishes are delicious and interesting and, while on the smaller size, it always leaves me wanting to come back for more. One of my favorite things on the menu is actually the yogurt dessert. Really light and beautiful; a perfect way to end a meal. I also really appreciate the casual, but sophisticated decor of the place. The entire vibe is really unique, upscale but not stuffy or trying too hard.  The garden is absolutely beautiful and I'd recommend getting a cocktail out there before your meal.
No comment

Olmsted is where the hype lives up to your expectations. I've been twice now, for dinner and brunch. While you sometimes have to book a month out for a reservation, it's totally worth the wait. The actual restaurant is not huge, but the tables are spaced out well enough for it not to feel cramped. Brunch really knocked it out of the park. My boyfriend and I got 4 plates to share and it was more than enough food. We shared the Egg Rolls, Potato Latke, Spanakopita Shakshuka, and the Krapfen Rhubarb Donuts. The Egg Rolls were filled with housemade bacon, farm eggs and vermont cheddar--a combination inside an egg roll I never knew could taste so perfect. The Potato Latke was cooked to perfection and topped with lemon creme fraiche and smoked trout rod. Insane. So good. Honestly, everything we ate was insanely delicious. Whats so impressive is not only the inventiveness of the menu but the actual execution of it. The ONLY thing that I found to be a bit annoying was that a cup of coffee (which in my opinion tasted like diner coffee was $5 for a single cup which is a biiiiit much for the lackluster taste).

Everything was delicious! The watermelon sushi was luscious and refreshing. The carrot crepe amazing.. Serrano wrapped trout - melt in your mouth.  Also a nice selection of wine by the glass, as well as attentive and thoughtful service. I plan to go back as soon as I can get another reservation.

The lavender drink tastes like something you should lather on yourself rather than consume as a drink. I saw that it was bourbon based (I'm as whisky and bourbon drinker) and figured the lavender would be a nice change of pace. But it was too much. Im sticking with the hard stuff. That said the food was great. The beet salad was very tasty and refreshing,  and the rutabaga tagliatelle was  amazing! It had a pasta consistency even though it's a root. The cream and cheese was perfectly cooked with the rutabaga to give it that authentic pasta texture.

Olmsted definitely lives up to the hype. I'm not gonna give a rundown of everything we ate because I don't feel like writing that much. Just know that almost everything we ate was exceptional. There were a couple misses (Kale Rangoon and Popcorn Fish), but both were still good. They just weren't as amazing as the rest of the meal. Service was warm and non-pretentious.
Amazing service, impeccable plating and divine food! Cannot rave enough about this place.

Let me be honest this place is good, but I mean for the hassle it is to get a reservation...meh. I also think they have some great stuff but not all of it is mind blowing. This is a spot that is good but I don't think is worth the wait (to get a Ressie), the price (some stuff is really OVERPRICED), the backyard is cool and the drinks are fine. Again in that area there are some other better spots you can walk right into and have a seat.

Though this is no easy table to get, Olmsted is worth the hassle.  The dishes were tasty, creative, and flavorful.  Even the two desserts we ordered were a success (don't be tuned off by the yogurt .  It is quite good.).  The in our party enjoyed the trout, the carrots, duck, and "pasta" dishes.  The plates are small, even the entre size, but they are sufficient.

What a great little spot in Brooklyn! Inventive and fresh dishes with a serious farm to table feel. Some of my favorite dishes were the beef tartare and the long island duck two ways, especially loved the beautiful outdoor garden in the backyard where we had dessert + finished our bottle of wine. Cant wait till the outdoor deck opens! Will be back.

Olmsted is the MVP of restaurants in New York. Chef Baxtrom, who trained under two of the most highly regarded names in the business, serves up some of the most flavorful, creative food I've ever enjoyed, regardless of price point. But his ability to do this without having a single item on the menu above 24 dollars is simply remarkable. Furthermore, the lack of high priced options and pretentiousness makes Olmsted extremely comfortable for a relaxed meal any day of the week. Three of their dishes from my most recent experience at Olmsted stand out: delicious squash rings served on an actual tree - of sorts; extremely basic crab rangoon, with a very simply but equisite spin, served humbly, and for fun in a Chinese take-out container no less; and the most delicious duck dish - served two ways, both incredible - that I've ever encountered in my life. Beyond this, the service is superb, stacked with serious foodies who will happily offer their honest opinions. The drink menu is outstanding, with simply labeled cocktails disguising brilliant subtlety. And the atmosphere is as good as it gets, feeling like you're eating in the chef's garden; and that's before you go out into the actual back garden of the restaurant, where you can roast smores, keeping warm under blankets on a cold winter's night. Olmsted is simply amazing, and easily one of my 3 favorite restaurants in the world.
No comment

It's ok. A bit overrated. Decent food, creative but not that creative to justify the price. Service was excellent. Still...prices too high and portions too small and music and talking too loud. We got the carrot clam crepes (pretty good but tiny) and trout (really good but needed microsocooe to see it) and the scallops. Decent but not worth paying $15-$20 for 3 bites. They are very creative dishes, I will give them that. Creative is one thing. And "delicious to die for" is another. They get the first but not the second.

Farm to Table restaurant. Quite a unique taste. That watermelon sushi was actually refreshing but different. I would say the overall experience was great. It Ii be a bit pricey but it is expected from a farm to table restaurant. Great for a date and definitely need to book early. Parking is not so bad in that area.

Love love love this place. Had been meaning to visit within a few months of their first opening in the spring and eventually finally made it for my birthday in October. Fantastic service and great food. Additionally, the garden in the back only serves drinks and snacks while the bar serves the full menu. Love their simplicity and treatment of farm fresh ingredients allowed to shine. Cocktails are all great, decent wine selection, a list of additional beverages and a tea program. The desserts are also totally worth it. I revisited recently with a friend for a casual light dinner and drinks. We waited in the garden and sat at the bar and again service and food were great. Difficult to get reservations so must plan ahead.

Really good - with a party of 6 we ordered the whole menu. Most things were awesome and everything good. The savory donuts to begin with the chicken liver pate were excellent. All the duck dishes excelled.

My wife and I have been to Olmsted several times and always been impressed.  The kitchen has always been very accommodating for our vegetarian and vegan preferences, something that we truly appreciate!  Last night we had some great cocktails (negronis!), pea sushi and ridiculously tasty asparagus appetizers, followed by a delicious falafel, and an amazing spätzle.  Thank you once again!
The experience here is excellent. Great food and cocktails. Highly recommend for an evening out with friends.

Second time here. Do you know why it's considered one if the best restaurants in NYC? Because it is! Everything, absolutely everything is done right. Each course is so well thought out down to every single detail: the copper napkin rings, thin pottery dishes and cups, hanging plants and herbs, beautifully crafted plates. Service & staff is top notch, make you feel noticed and pampered without being overbearing. So cozy and consistently good you never want to leave. It's so rare when a place gets everything right. Cocktails and entrees are prepared with unparalleled artistry. Thank you Olmstead. Tip: having trouble with reservations, try the seats by the kitchen - best seats in the house.
